Award.AwardTitle: Inspiration, Frustration, and Fascination: An Excursion into Low-Oxidation State Main Group Chemistry
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Gregory H. Robinson of the Department of Chemistry at The University of Georgia will pursue an ambitious program to explore challenging areas of low-oxidation state main group chemistry. The work will demonstrate that N-heterocyclic carbenes and their N-heterocyclic dicarbene derivatives constitute a unique platform from which many unusual low-oxidation state main group species may be obtained. Major goals in the proposed work include: (a) the synthesis of unusual species containing one-coordinate borocations; (b) the synthesis of two-coordinate borylenes; (c) the carbene-stabilization of a Si(0) atom and a parent silylene; and (d) the preparation of extended molecular systems integrated with main group diatomic allotrope moieties. These targeted low-oxidation state species may further be utilized in the synthesis of other unusual main group molecules such as NHC-stabilized boron analogs of carbonyl derivatives.

This project utilizes a class of organic bases to stabilize highly reactive diatomic molecules such as disilicon, diphosphorus, and diarsenic at room temperature. This proposal describes efforts to further study the synthesis, structure, and reactivity of these base-stabilized diatomics. It is possible that these base-stabilized diatomics may have applications related to new ways to deposit elemental silicon or phosphorus in the fabrication of advanced electronics and computer chips and chemical catalysis. Indeed, Professor Robinson and coworkers were recently granted a US patent (No.: 8278456) for their discovery of using organic bases to stabilize diatomic molecules.

Institution.Name: University of Georgia Research Foundation Inc
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA RESEARCH FOUNDATION, INC.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The generous funding of the National Science Foundation has enabled us to make a number of significant discoveries regarding earth abundant main group elements and the organic bases known as N-heterocyclic carbenes (NHCs). This has contributed to high intellectual merit contributions in that this work has been published is high impact chemistry research journals. In addition, the students engaged in this work gained highly valued skills in synthetic inorganic chemistry and the manipulation of air- and water sensitive compounds. Indeed, a number of young women have worked on this project and have chosen to pursue careers in chemistry. In addition, the Principal Investigator has honed an introduction chemistry course entitled, Molecules That Changed History. This course serves as an introduction to some of the historically interesting compounds in context with world events at the time.

This laboratory made a number of important fundamental discoveries in this last year of funding.

One such finding concerns the transformation of the N-heterocyclic carbene into a derivative known as an anionic N-heterocyclic dicarbene (HHDC) and subsequent reaction of this species with silicon tetrachloride to give an NHC with SiCl3 bonding on the backside of the organic base (C4 position). The reactivity of this compound was explored and produced interesting findings related to low-oxidation state silicon compounds. (Dalton Trans. 2016, 45, 5941)

Another important accomplishment concerned the stabilization, or "chemical trapping", of a silylene--silicon analogs of the organic bases N-heterocyclic carbenes (based on carbon). Specifically, silylenes are extremely elusive chemical species containing a silicon atom with two chemical groups attached (:SiR2). We were successful in trapping the monochlorosilylene [:SiHCl] species between two Fe(CO)3 units--at room temperature. (J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2016, 138, 9799)

Another imprtant research finding was to link two N-Heterocyclic carbenes via a ferrocenyl unit thereby promising the possibility of a polymeric species containing these useful organic bases. (Dalton Trans. 2017, 46, 5508)

In addition to the primary research articles, a number of the discoveries made by this laboratory, as a result of this NSF funding, have been subsequently highlighted in such scientific news outlets as Chemical & Engineering News, ChemistryWorld, and Nature Chemistry. Overall, twelve research aritcles resulted from this work, many of which were published in some of the most prestigious chemistry research journals. The funding of such fundamental chemistry research by the National Science Foundation will allow us to better understand the chemistry of earth abundant elements. This will ultimately translate into a better understanding of our world.


Last Modified: 06/06/2017
Modified by: Gregory H Robinson
